section.title: Printing
section.para: Most printers will be automatically supported by Xubuntu. Printers can be added and configured using the Xubuntu Settings Manager.

section.title: Local Printing
section.para: A local printer is one which is directly connected to your computer (as opposed to a network printer, discussed in the following section). To setup a new local printer:

step.para: Obtain the model name of your printer.
Ensure the printer is turned on.

Choose
Applications Settings Printing .
Now choose New Printer.
Enter a name, description and location for your printer. Then click Forward.
Your printer should be automatically detected and should appear at the top of the list of devices on the left. If so, make sure it is selected and click Forward.

If you have a PostScript Printer Description (PPD) file for you printer, select Provide PPD File then click the icon next to None and select the file you wish to use. Otherwise, make sure Select Printer From Database is selected and select the manufacturer of your printer from the list. After you have finished, click Forward.

Now select your printer model and the driver you wish you use from the lists. If your printer was automatically detected the best choices should already be selected for you. Once you have done this click Forward then click Apply.

note.para: If your printer was not automatically detected, you can try to select the port and printer driver manually. Some printers need further setup. Search the databases at LinuxPrinting.org or check the Printer page on the Ubuntu Wiki for possible information on your printer.

section.title: Network Printing
section.para: You can also configure your Xubuntu system to send print jobs to a remote print server. Remote printers are hosted somewhere on a network.
First you will need to install the gnome-cups-manager application. This will allow you to easily set up your network printer. You can do this using Synaptic Package Manager:

step.para: Enter your password when prompted.
Click Search from the menu bar.
Enter gnome-cups-manager and click Search.

Click on the menu item gnome-cups-manager then from the menu select
Package Mark for Installation
Click the Apply button in the menu bar then click the Apply button in the dialog box that pops up.
Click Close then exit Synaptic Package Manager

section.para: To configure your remote printer once gnome-cups-manager has been installed:

step.para: Obtain the model name of your printer.
Ensure the printer is turned on.

Choose
Applications Settings Printing .

You can scan for these printers and have them configure automatically. To do this, click
Global Settings Detect LAN Printers
. A warning box will appear indicating that a port will be opened on your computer that could potentially be used for malicious purposes. It is recommended you only run this scan on a trusted local network. If you donâ€™t trust the network 100 percent, cancel the scan. If you are willing to go ahead, click OK and after a minute or so the printers will appear in the box.

If the previous step does not succeed, you can setup the remote printer manually. Choose
Printer Add Printer .
Select Network Printer, and then select the appropriate protocol from the drop down menu.
Insert the details of the network printer and click Forward.
Select the printer model and then click Apply.
Finally, you can enter in a description and location for your printer.

note.para: If you do not know the protocol or details of your network printer, you should consult your network administrator.

section.title: Testing a Printer
section.para: To test whether a local or remote printer works correctly:

step.para:
Choose
Applications Settings Printing .
Select the printer you would like to test from the list on the left.
Click Print Test Page. A page should then be sent for printing.

section.title: Faxing
section.para: efax-gtk can be used to send and receive faxes using a fax modem.

It also has an interface to provide a virtual printer for sending faxes from word processors and similar programs, can automatically e-mail a received fax to a designated user, and can automatically print a received fax.
You can install the efax-gtk package from the Universe repository (see Add Applications).

To run efax-gtk, choose
Applications Office Efax-gtk .

note.para: efax-gtk requires a supported fax modem to be installed for it to function correctly.

section.title: Scanning
section.para: Most scanners are automatically supported by Xubuntu, and should be easy to install and operate. This guide will walk you through how to use your scanner and what to do if Xubuntu cannot find your scanner.

section.title: Does my scanner work with Ubuntu?
section.para: There are three ways to see if you scanner works in Xubuntu:

step.para: Simply plug it in and try it! If it is a newer Universal Serial Bus (USB) scanner, it is likely that it will just work.
Check https://wiki.ubuntu.com/HardwareSupportComponentsScanners which is Ubuntu specific.
SANE project listing of support scanners - The SANE (Scanner Access Now Easy) project provides most of the backends to the scanning software on Ubuntu.

section.title: Using your scanner
section.para: Most of the time, Xubuntu will simply detect your scanner and you just be able to use it. To scan a document, you need to follow these steps:

step.para: Place what you want to scan on the scanner.

Choose
Applications Graphics XSane Image Scanner .
Alternately, pressing the scan button on the scanner should also work.

section.title: What if it says No devices available?
section.para: There are two reasons why you might get this message.

step.para: Your scanner is not supported in Xubuntu. The most common type of scanners not supported are old parallel port scanners or Lexmark All-in-One printer/scanner/faxes.
The driver for your scanner is not being autoloaded.

section.title: Manually installing a scanner
section.para: There are some scanners that have less than complete drivers from the SANE project. They can sometimes be used, but not all the features may work.

step.para:
Make sure the Universe repository is enabled. The easiest way to do this is through Synaptic. Launch Synaptic by choosing
Applications System Synaptic Package Manager . Then from the menus select
Settings Repositories . Check the box next to Universe if it is not already checked. Click on Close then click the Reload button to refresh the package listings.
Get the drivers by searching Synaptic. Click Search then enter libsane-extras in the dialog and press Search.

Edit the /etc/sane.d/dll.conf and enable the right driver for your scanner. You can do this by pressing Alt-F2 on your keyboard then typing sudo gedit /etc/sane.d/dll.conf and pressing Run. Look for the lines that say:

screen.computeroutput: # The following backends are not part of the SANE distribution # but are provided by the libsane-extras Debian package

step.para: Below these lines are several commented out lines (they begin with #). Uncomment (delete the #) the right one for your scanner.
Fire up XSane and scan away.

note.para: Because of the way hotplugging works in Xubuntu, you may need to plug in the scanner after the computer has booted. If you're having problems seeing the scanner, you might want to try this.

section.title: XSane Image Scanner
section.para: You can use XSane to control a scanner and acquire images from it. With XSane, you can easily photocopy documents and save, fax or e-mail your scanned images. It can even save your scans as multi-page documents, instead of separate, one-page files. The Xsane website has more information.

step.para:
To start XSane choose
Applications Graphics XSane Image Scanner .

note.para:
XSane can also be used from within The GIMP; just click
File Acquire XSane to scan directly into an image.
